;在香港纪律部队庆祝成立之际，北京向香港纪律部队保证坚定不移的支持在加拿大举行的世界警察和消防运动会上获得了有史以来最好的奖牌数量。

;

;周二，该市代表队在今年的世界警察和消防运动会上赢得了 275 枚奖牌，他们在履行职责时得到了支持，在加拿大举行。

;

;香港派出了一支由 350 人组成的代表队（主要由警察部队的运动员组成）参加这项每两年举办一次的赛事。

;

;奖牌总数包括 97 枚金牌、90 枚银牌和 88 枚铜牌，这是香港在奥运会上最成功的表现。

;

;但香港参与在温尼伯举行的这项赛事也引发了争议和抱怨，认为香港出于人权原因，不应允许警察参与竞争。

;

;加拿大的一些活动人士对香港警察受到欢迎感到不满，并强调了 2019 年社会骚乱期间针对抗议者的所谓暴力行为。

;

;但北京设立的三个负责香港事务的机构谴责“反中乱港分子”在周日结束的奥运会期间骚扰香港队。

;

;国务院港澳事务发言人港澳办对周二回国的香港队的出色表现表示祝贺。

;

;他表示：“我们向他们致以崇高敬意和热烈祝贺。”

;< p>;发言人补充说，中央对香港纪律部队充满信心，支持他们依法履职。

;

;矛头直指“反中乱港分子”发言人表示：“我们对这些卑鄙行为和令人作呕的表演表示最强烈的谴责。”

;

;数千名警察巡逻香港天安门广场周年纪念日

;

;北京驻香港维护国家安全办公室通过其微信账号向该团队表示祝贺，并赞扬制服部队在2019年社会动荡期间的辛勤工作。

;< p>;该办公室表示，他们为香港由混乱走向秩序、由稳定走向繁荣做出了贡献。

;

;“反中乱港分子对香港纪律部队的抹黑，清楚地表明： ……他们是违法分子的克星。”

;

;中联办发言人还痛批“逃亡海外的反中乱港分子”以及“一些人”。西方政客和反华团体”试图将体育赛事政治化。

;

;发言人表示，中央政府将支持政府将那些“逃离香港的扰乱分子”绳之以法。

;

;发言人表示，中央政府将支持政府将那些“逃离香港的破坏分子”绳之以法。 p>;

;香港国安警察上个月悬赏 100 万港元（合 128,000 美元），奖励提供信息以逮捕八名反对派人士，其中包括出生于加拿大的郭永亨。

;

;一些居住在加拿大的香港人在奥运会开幕式上抗议该市代表队。

;

;香港人利用宽松的要求申请加入警察

;

;反对派政客保守党也对加拿大政府允许香港官员入境参加比赛表示失望。

;

;香港政府二号人物、布政司陈国基于周二在机场，并表示球队让这座城市感到自豪。

;

;陈还批评了一些“别有用心”的人试图将体育赛事政治化。

;

;“这些事件曾经发生过再次表明，不稳定势力仍未放弃……并利用各种借口和场合对香港纪律部队进行污蔑抹黑，肆意抹黑攻击香港，企图破坏香港的国际形象和繁荣稳定。

;

;陈补充说，反港势力对香港稳定和国家安全的影响不容小视。

;

;今年的奥运会于7月28日至8月6日举行。 ，是一项奥林匹克式的比赛，有来自全球 50 多个国家和地区的代表警察部门、其他执法机构和消防员的 8,500 多名运动员参加。

;反性暴力危机中心敦促香港隐私监管机构提供更大的保护RainLily 周二表示，从 2021 年 4 月到 2023 年 3 月，它收到了 646 份与图像性暴力相关的援助请求。它已帮助个人要求在线平台删除 1,342 张未经同意的亲密内容照片。其中近 1,200 张（即 89%）最终被删除。

;

;该非政府组织表示，许多案例都试图删除显示面部特征的单张照片。但根据《个人资料（私隐）条例》，在没有其他个人资料的情况下传播私密影像并不违法。

;

;“个人资料私隐专员公署应进一步检讨隐私图像在什么级别可以被定义为个人数据，并以更积极主动的方式帮助那些遭受非自愿传播隐私图像的人，以满足公众的期望。”

;

;专员公署表示，一般来说，如果相关个人的身份被确定为亲密图像，则可能构成该条例规定的个人资料。

;

;副执行董事Doris Chong 表示，RainLily 注意到，要求帮助删除网上私密照片的请求有所增加。

;

;“尽管 2021 年 10 月引入了特定的刑事犯罪，但 RainLily 的一线经验表明，那些面临未经同意的分发和威胁的人”她说。

;

;菅直人补充说，非政府组织要求在线平台删除图像的服务有助于避免受害者身份暴露。

;

;数据显示，大多数受害者是女性（71.3%），而大约五分之一（22.2%）是男性。

;

;该非政府组织处理的图片中有一半是由受害者认识的人分发的，包括亲密伴侣（27.5%）和网上熟人（15.8%）。但三分之一的受害者无法识别发布照片的人。

;

;Kan 表示，大多数受害者担心这些照片会被亲人发现。

;

;“他们担心家人、朋友和同事可以在网上找到这些图片。即使内容被删除，他们仍然害怕这些图像被再次上传，甚至在网上受到身体羞辱，这对受害者造成了创伤。

;

;在 1,342 张亲密照片中，42%它们是在色情网站上发现的，其中近四分之一是在社交媒体平台上发现的（25%），其他是在搜索引擎上发现的（22.7%）。其余的则在内容农场（5.3％）和图像托管网站（5％）上发现。

;

;但是，RainLily 透露了帮助受害者删除图像的各种挑战。

;< p>;该非政府组织表示，与其他平台相比，色情网站上发布的内容以“指数级规模”传播，25 个网站从未对非政府组织做出回应，也没有采取删除行动。

;

;近 40% 的香港人香港青少年接触不良性内容：民意调查

;

;大多数网站只禁止侵犯所有者版权的材料。但未经同意的亲密图像的版权大部分属于“摄影师”，这给彻底删除此类内容带来了困难。

;

;该非政府组织还指出，Telegram 上的频道经常发布内容农场网站的链接。内容农场上的帖子包括未经同意的图片、受害者的个人信息以及围绕该图片捏造的故事。

;

;相同的内容在这些频道的子群体中传播。这些分支机构拥有成百上千的订阅者。

;

;报告遭受网络性骚扰的男性多于女性：调查

;

;“虽然这些平台有政策和举报渠道，但他们不回应和举报Kan 说。

;

;基于图像的性暴力相关刑事犯罪于 2021 年生效。不过，该非政府组织表示定罪率和起诉率较低。

;

;它说法律有局限性。例如，当肇事者被指控时，没有法律义务删除所分发的内容；这些图片只有在法律诉讼开始后才会被删除，但为时已晚，无法阻止这些图片在网上传播。

;意大利北部贝加莫附近一家乳品厂的老板在货架上装载着数千件物品后死亡奶酪轮倒塌并把他埋了。

;

;整个晚上，救援人员试图从大量坚硬的格拉纳帕达诺奶酪下面救出这名男子，每轮奶酪重 40 公斤。

;

;Giacomo Chiapparini消防队员安东尼奥·杜西 (Antonio Dusi) 说，74 岁的他仓库里的一个架子破裂，产生多米诺骨牌效应，导致奶酪倒塌，他被埋在了奶酪下面。

;

;救援人员“必须用手移动奶酪和架子， ”杜西说，并补充说，“花了大约 12 个小时”才终于找到了基亚帕里尼。

;

;周日晚上，这名男子正在他位于米兰不远的小镇的乳品厂的仓库里工作，当时一名男子发现了他的尸体。正在成熟的大奶酪轮上的金属架子倒塌了。

;

;很快，高高的架子一直延伸到天花板，里面堆满了奶酪，一个接一个地倒塌，直到埋葬了该男子，说发言人说。

;

;最高的架子高达 10 米（33 英尺）。

;

;目前尚不清楚第一个金属架子是如何倒塌的，但怀疑是材料疲劳或技术故障造成的。发言人补充说，预计将进行调查以确定是一颗还是几轮奶酪杀死了该男子。

;

;仓库位于小镇位于贝加莫附近的罗马诺迪伦巴第亚 (Romano di Lombardia)，总共装有 25,000 轮格拉纳帕达诺奶酪 (Grana Padano)，这是一种类似于帕尔马干酪的硬奶酪，在意大利非常受欢迎。

;马来西亚总检察长撤销了涉及副总理艾哈迈德的腐败案件的首席检察官扎希德·哈米德 (Zahid Hamid) 申请提前退休后，批评者担心政治干预审判的程度仅次于 1MDB 丑闻。

;

;艾哈迈德·扎希德 (Ahmad Zahid) 是总理安瓦尔·易卜拉欣 (Anwar Ibrahim) 政府的重要成员，该政府巫统和国阵 (BN) 联盟的昔日竞争对手。

;

;扎希德曾担任总理纳吉布·拉扎克的副手，他于 2018 年被指控犯有 47 项腐败、滥用权力和贿赂罪，涉及超过 72 名据称，他的百万林吉特（1580万美元）与他的家族慈善基金会有关。

;

;马来西亚巫统正在努力应对马来人基础的下降和民意调查临近时的软形象

;

;在周二的一份声明中总检察长伊德鲁斯·哈伦 (Idrus Harun) 表示，他根据副检察官拉贾·罗泽拉·拉贾·托兰 (Raja Rozela Raja Toran) 在 4 月份提出的提前退休申请，将她从该案中免职。

;

;“该申请已获得批准并将生效” 2023 年 11 月 1 日，”Idrus 说。

;

;Raja Rozela 将从 8 月 30 日开始休假，他补充道。

;

;Raja 从 2018 年一开始就负责起诉工作。罗泽拉将案件审理至 2022 年 1 月，当时吉隆坡高等法院认定检方已对副总理立案，并命令他进行辩护。

;

;她的职位由杜苏基·莫赫塔尔 (Dusuki Mokhtar) 接替。负责公共利益和重大案件的部门负责人，拥有30多年的高级检察官经验。

;

;总检察长发表声明之前，马来西亚狂野的社交媒体上充斥着各种猜测

;

;反对党土团党法律与宪法局副局长萨莎·莱娜·阿都拉提夫对在审判的关键时刻将拉惹·罗泽拉免职提出质疑，称这给马来西亚司法自由带来了负面印象。

;

;“任何表明存在干涉或国家对腐败软弱的迹象或看法都会对我们作为商业场所的声誉产生不利影响，”周六参加州选举的萨沙·莱纳(Sasha Lyna)说。 “没有人愿意与腐败政权做生意。”

;

;马来西亚的安瓦尔任命腐败缠身的艾哈迈德·扎希德·哈米迪为副总理

;

;艾哈迈德·扎希德重返内阁是在选举陷入僵局之后。 2022 年 11 月大选。

;

;在他与安瓦尔·易卜拉欣 (Anwar Ibrahim) 的希盟 (PH) 联盟结成不太可能的联盟后，他的回归引发了一波关于这对正在进行的审判意味着什么的猜测。自 1998 年以来，他一直是国阵联盟的死敌。

;

;7 月，反对派国民联盟 (PN) 联盟指责安瓦尔达成协议，撤销对艾哈迈德·扎希德的指控，以换取国阵支持安瓦尔竞选

;

;安瓦尔表示，他去年 11 月任命丑闻缠身的艾哈迈德·扎希德 (Ahmad Zahid) 为副手，这意味着每个人在被证明有罪之前都是无辜的。安瓦尔本人在 1999 年和 2014 年被监禁期间一直坚称自己是清白的。

;

;然而，总检察长的解释并没有平息猜测，马来西亚公众指出，伊德鲁斯的前任阿卜杜勒·甘尼·帕泰尔也同样被免职。以健康原因为幌子下台。

;

;这是在他于 2016 年试图因 1MDB 丑闻逮捕时任总理纳吉布之后。

;由城市公司建造的香港首辆电动小巴将于作为推动绿色交通的一部分，将于今年年底推出。

;

;信兴新能源董事总经理周二表示，其价值 200 万港元（256,000 美元）的 Moonca 模型是第一个获得环境保护部批准的模型Department，旨在打入新兴的电动小巴市场。

;

;信兴集团子公司的负责人 Gary Ng Fuk-keung 补充道，这款新车是不可避免的赚钱起点迈向电动公共交通。

;

;“我们希望打入小巴市场。这是大势所趋，香港的小巴迟早都会转为电动车。”吴说。

;

;“每辆小巴的售价约为200万港元。预计今年年底交付首批车辆。”

;

;信兴集团是香港最大的电器分销商之一。

;

;该集团的生产推广电动小巴是该署斥资 8,000 万港元推广电动公共小巴试验计划的一部分。

;

;;2023.08.08 21:00;
;;

;被称为中国北方粮仓的地区的农民恳求帮助减轻作物损失from floods as Typhoon Khanun threatens output with more heavy rainfall that could bring bugs and blight.

;

;Water levels across Heilongjiang province have been falling since Monday after Typhoon Doksuri caused flooding across northern China since Friday, but farmers are struggling to rescue the most affected crops in the nation's top grain-producing region.

;

;In two days, videos uploaded by farmers asking for assistance went viral on Chinese social media, as they feared that all of the silt that has accumulated on blossoming rice crops could reduce yields.

;

;“We want to use a high-pressure water gun to flush the silt off, but this is too much work, and we desperately need help from real experts from all fields,” a Heilongjiang woman said in one of the videos.

;

;Typhoon Doksuri hit China's northeastern provinces of Heilongjiang, Jilin and Liaoning, known as the country's breadbasket. They contributed more than one-fifth of the country's grain production, one-fourth of the country's grain commodities, and one-third of its grain export last year, data from the State Council shows.

;

;More frequent extreme weather is ringing alarms across China's agriculture sector, intensifying Beijing's push for self-sufficiency amid rising tensions with the US and global market disruptions stemming from the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

;

;Heilongjiang's Wuchang city, known for the country's best-quality rice, has seen a small percentage of its farmland – more than 2,720 hectares (6,721 acres) – affected by flooding, including 2,436 hectares of rice, according to China's Ministry of Emergency Management on Friday. In total, the city has 194,266 hectares of rice farmland.

;

;Wuchang's agricultural output accounted for more than 40 per cent of the region's gross domestic product, and its rice production reached 1.92 million tonnes in 2022.

;

;Beijing steps up food security with stiff assessments of local-level cadres

;

;In 2021, the city accounted for 2.6 per cent of Heilongjiang's total grain output, while the province itself accounted for 14 per cent, 15 per cent and 44 per cent of the national production of rice, corn and soybeans, respectively, data from Guosheng Securities showed on Sunday.

;

;From August 1-4, the province's Shangzhi city saw its heaviest rainfall since 1957, resulting in crop damage that has affected more than 42,575 hectares, Xinhua said on Sunday.

;

;Jilin province's Shulan city, an important maize producer in China, has also been battered by floods, with more than 14,466 hectares of arable lands being affected, and loss estimates surpassing 43 million yuan, Thepaper.cn reported on Monday.

;

;Last week, China's Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs arranged for 432 million yuan worth of disaster relief and dispatched 11 working groups and hundreds of experts to grain-producing areas to provide technical guidance on preventing pests and improving yields.

;

;“When rice gets silt, it's not realistic to wash it down with a high-pressure water gun, it would be too costly to do so,” said Huang Bangquan, a professor specialising in plant genetics at Hubei University.

;

;“Rice yields will definitely be reduced [this time], but not to the point of losing the harvest,” said Huang, adding that even if the rice is contaminated with silt during the flowering period, it can still be self-fertilised.

;

;But he also warned that flooding leads to more pests and diseases in crops, making these the leading risks currently facing farmers in the northeast.

;

;“For some regions that are at risk of crops being wiped out, farmers could opt to grow some short-season crops in time, which would more or less make up their losses,” Huang said.

;

;What is the state of China's food-security drive, and is it succeeding?

;

;China's summer harvest fell for the first time since 2018, largely due to the rains that hit the wheat-growing province of Henan in late May amid the harvest season.

;

;On Monday, China's Ministry of Emergency Management said the current flood-control and post-disaster reconstruction tasks are considerable, and Typhoon Khanun looms.

;

;“[With another typhoon coming], the situation of flood control and relief is unpromising and arduous,” Minister Wang Xiangxi said.

;

;Huang added that the agriculture sector needs to be more prepared for extreme weather in the long term, with measures taken to protect forests and grasslands, build more water facilities, and breed crop varieties that can grow amid extreme weather.

;A Chinese woman who overstayed in Singapore for more than seven years claimed she did so for her son's education and that it was “worth it”.

;

;Kang Lihong, 48, was sentenced to the maximum six months on Tuesday for overstaying in Singapore under the Immigration Act.

;

;She also received a S$2,000 (US$1,480) fine in lieu of caning as she cannot be caned since she is a woman.

;

;The court heard that Kang was last issued a long-term visit pass valid from March 2015 to April 2016.

;

;When her pass expired, she was given a 62-day visit pass that was valid until June, in order for her to leave the country.

;

;He was fired. Then he padlocked his ex-colleagues inside their Singapore office

;

;However, Kang did not leave Singapore. Instead, she remained illegally in the country for seven years, one month and 10 days.

;

;She was arrested by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority at her address on August 1 this year.

;

;The woman was remanded and appeared in court via video-link. She did not have a lawyer.

;

;Speaking through a Mandarin interpreter, Kang said: “The reason why I overstayed is because my child was studying in secondary school, so if I go back to China, I'm afraid that my child cannot stay in Singapore.”

;

;She said her son was “still very young”, so she wanted to stay in Singapore to take care of him.

;

;“After my child graduated and started working, my child asked me to go back to China, but then Covid-19 happened so I was not able to fly back,” said Kang.

;

;She claimed that she “already had the intention to surrender” but ICA arrested her.

;

;“I hope that my case will not affect my child,” she said.

;

;When the judge asked her how old her son currently was, she said he was 25.

;

;“Why would the child be studying in secondary school, and the child is 25 today?” asked the judge.

;

;The woman answered that he studied for five years in secondary school.

;

;She added that air tickets were very expensive when Covid-19 struck, after her son graduated.

;

;“I was afraid if I go back to China, and anything bad happens, it would be very troublesome. So that is why I overstayed,” she said.

;

;The prosecution pointed out that the woman's son was already 18 at the beginning of her offences.

;

;“So in that sense, she is not required to remain in Singapore to take care of her child,” he said.

;

;The woman answered that no one was paying for her son's school fees when he was in polytechnic. “如果我不留在这里，他的教育就会停止，”她说。 “He couldn't pay his own school fees.”

;

;She added that there is “no choice” as a mother, adding that she was proud of her son and had to support him as his father was unable to.

;

;“I admit my mistake but I think it's worth it,” she said.

;

;In sentencing, the judge said the reasons given by the accused for offending were insufficient, with no extreme or exceptional circumstances that qualified as mitigating.

;

;After hearing the sentence, the woman asked repeatedly if the sentence could be shorter.

;

;

;“The decision stands,” said the judge, and the woman started to cry, saying she wanted to call her son and asking “can't it be shorter”.

;

;Hong Kong customs officers have arrested a cosmetics saleswoman on suspicion of laundering nearly HK$900 million (US$115 million) in alleged crime proceeds through 13 bank accounts using two shell companies.

;

;The 39-year-old woman was detained in Tsuen Wan on Tuesday after officers from customs' financial investigation bureau raided her flat.

;

;Inspector Michael Ng Sze-chai of the bureau said the suspect was allegedly a core member of a local money-laundering syndicate that had processed HK$896 million in illegal funds through the 13 accounts between May 2021 and January this year.

;

;An investigation revealed that the woman had set up two shell companies on three days in January 2021, according to the Customs and Excise Department.

;

;“The two companies claimed that they were involved in the import and export business and the trading of cargo such as electronic products, but the investigation found they had no actual business,” Ng said.

;

;He added that the woman, who worked as a cosmetics saleswoman and earned about HK$10,000 a month, had allegedly set up the 13 bank accounts used to launder the funds over a 21-month period.

;

;“The suspected crime proceeds [in local and US dollars] came from about 600 bank accounts through about 1,800 transactions,” he said, adding that most of the accounts were set up in Hong Kong.

;

;“All of the illegal funds were then transferred out of the 13 bank accounts in hundreds of transactions and moved to another 100 bank accounts.”

;

;The largest single transaction amounted to HK$9.4 million, according to the inspector.

;

;A source familiar with the case said that most of the 700-plus accounts involved in the money-laundering case belonged to shell companies that were set up by travellers from mainland China and other places.

;

;Hong Kong police arrest 19 in crackdown on money laundering syndicate

;

;“They set up the companies and business bank accounts and then left the city,” the insider added.

;

;Customs officers began investigating the syndicate about three months ago after suspicious transactions were detected in one of the business accounts belonging to the suspect.

;

;After gathering evidence, officers from the financial investigation bureau, which was set up on August 1, arrested the woman on Tuesday.

;

;She was detained on suspicion of money laundering – an offence punishable by up to 14 years in jail and a HK$5 million fine. As of Tuesday evening, she was still being held for questioning.

;

;Ng said customs was investigating the origin of the illegal funds, how the cash was generated and its final destination.

;

;Hong Kong student among 6 arrested as police clamp down on money laundering group

;

;Before the bureau was officially set up this month, the financial investigation division under the syndicate crimes investigation bureau was responsible for investigating money-laundering activities.

;

;The new bureau, led by Senior Superintendent Suzette Ip Tung-ching, has more than 90 officers.

;

;So far this year, customs officers have intercepted six other money-laundering cases involving HK$11 billion in suspected crime proceeds and arrested a total of 46 people.

;

;In June, officers smashed a money-laundering syndicate that had allegedly smuggled US$91 million in suspected crime proceeds into the city from Turkey using air passengers. Twenty-three local men were arrested in connection with the case.

;

;In May, they arrested a jobless public housing tenant accused of running a syndicate that had laundered HK$3.5 billion in illegal proceeds. He was among eight people detained in the operation.

;

;Hong Kong customs cracks second-largest money-laundering case in HK$3.5 billion arrest

;

;The city's largest money-laundering case – involving HK$13.1 billion – came to light in 2012 when police arrested a 22-year-old man from the mainland. The amount was the highest recorded in two decades for a money-laundering case involving bulk cash smuggling operations using air couriers.

;

;In the first seven months of this year, the Joint Financial Intelligence Unit, comprising police and customs officers, handled 48,026 reports of suspicious financial activity. Figures showed an increase in such cases from 51,588 in 2019 to 68,538 in 2022.

;

;In Hong Kong, banks, securities and insurance firms, legal and accounting professionals, dealers in precious metals and stones, money service operators, money lenders and property agents are required to report suspicious transactions.
